params.value: Will not be shown in Event UI

params.title: Script Source
params.value:
#!/usr/bin/env bash

# Enter your shell script code here
# Press F11 to toggle full screen mode
# To get workflow's job argument refer to $JOB_ARG env variable

# am I windows?
echo $PSVersionTable

echo "print integer with % to report progress (e.g. 20%)"
 sleep 2; echo "$(date)"; echo 10%
 sleep 2; echo "$(date)"; echo 40%
 sleep 2; echo "$(date)"; echo 90%
 sleep 2
echo '{"perf":{"step3":55,"step2":30,"step1":20}}'

params.title: STDIN Script
params.value:
echo "STARTED"

# set trap command for proper termination handling
echo "trap: kill $$"

sleep 15
echo "COMPLETED"

# to specify host use full URI (sftp://user:Password@host:port)
# or keep that URI as env variable and specify variable name
# keep blank or localhost to run command locally (without ssh)
# if using ssh key
# sftp://user@host:port?privateKey=/path/to/file&passphrase=Password)
# you can also keep ssh key in SSH Key parameter
# if password contains special character use URI escape characters (e.g. @ => %40)

# if using with WF plugin host could be specified via Job Argument parameter

# many interpreters (besides sh/bash) will support execution from stdin
# node -
# python -
# pwsh -c -
# some will need a file to be created, if so try smth like
# cat - > /tmp/myfile && groovy myfile

# This should work the same way on Windows machines too (if openssh installed)
# powershell -

# Please note that aborting SSH job won't terminate you remote command
# You can specify termination command by printing it out with "trap:" prefix, e.g.
# echo "trap: kill $$" or "trap: kill -9 -$$"

params.title: Script
params.value:
#!/bin/sh

echo "Running SSHX job on $HOSTNAME"

sleep 10

# Specify conneciton info using URI format:
# [ssh://]user[:Password]@host[:port]?[privateKey=/path/to/file&passphrase=Password]
# URI can be passed directly or as a reference to environment variable
# If passing password via URI, you'd need to encode special characters (e.g. @ => %40)
# You can also set SSH_KEY/SSH_PASSWORD/SSH_PASSPHRASE as variables in event/plugin secrets

# If no SSH Host specified on event parameters, it can be resolved from WF argument

# Kill Command parameter is used to properly handle job abortion
# Default command is [pkill -S $$]
# $$ is refering to PID of your script parent process (bootstrap script)

# To pass variables other then JOB_ / ARG*, use SSH_ prefix on variable name
# If this event is chained by other job, you can access chain data using CHAIN_DATA variable

params.title: Script
params.value:
#!/bin/sh

echo "Running Docker job on $HOSTNAME"

cat /etc/os-release

ls -lah chain_data || echo "no chain data"

# If Docker Host is not specified, docker socket will be used
# To access remote docker machine via ssh (on top of socket) specify DH as:
# ssh://user[:password]@host[:port]
# To specify ssh credentials you can also use SSH_PASSWORD/SSH_KEY env varaibles
# To access remote docker instance with exposed http:
# http://dockerhost:2375  (there is no auth options for that at this point)
# To specify image registry credentials use DOCKER_USER, DOCKER_PASSWORD variables
# All credential variables can be set via event/plugin secrets

# This script will be used as an entrypoint on the container (mounted as /cronicle.sh by default).
# To use original entrypoint check corresponding checkbox below,
#  and use command parameter above to pass argument to it
# If this job is chained by other event, chain data will be mounted to the container
#   as chain_data file 

# In order to pass variables to container (other than JOB_ and ARG*) it should start with DOCKER_

# If job is aborted "docker stop" is invoked (SIGTERM), docker will send SIGKILL after some time
# Try to handle SIGTERM in your script for proper shutdown on abortion

storage.title: stdin
storage.script:
let prefix = process.env['PREFIX'] || 'JOB_'

let env = Object.entries(process.env)
  .filter(e => e[0].startsWith(prefix))
  .map(e => ({name: e[0], value: e[1].substring(0,80)}))
  
console.table(env)

console.log(JSON.stringify({complete:1, code:0}))

params.title: Report error on any job failure

storage.title: General
storage.description: For events that don't fit anywhere else.

storage.title: base_app_url
storage.description: overrides app url displayed in notifications

storage.title: ad_domain
storage.description: default AD domain for external auth. You can also prepend domain to the username (e.g. user@domain.com)

storage.title: smtp_hostname
storage.description: SMTP server (port 25 is used default)

storage.title: email_from
storage.description: Notification sender

storage.title: admin_web_hook
storage.description:
Webhook for activity log notifications. Uses slack markdown.
Tip: use cronicle run api to handle notification with custom event

storage.title: custom_live_log_socket_url
storage.description:
!this requires browser page refresh
overrides the host for live log connection. On multinode cluster this can be assigned to each node, e.g. 
custom_live_log_socket_url.manager
custom_live_log_socket_url.worker1
Can specify custom port too. This is useful if using reverse proxy or docker/swarm

storage.title: web_hook_text_templates.job_complete
storage.description: Success notification (slack markdown by default)

storage.title: web_hook_text_templates.job_failure
storage.description: Error notification (slack markdown by default)

storage.title: web_hook_text_templates.job_start
storage.description: Start notification (slack markdown by default)

storage.title: web_hook_text_templates.job_warning
storage.key: ‚ö†Ô∏è *[event_title]* completed with warning on [hostname]: Warning: _*[description]*_ <[job_details_url] | More details>
storage.description: Warning notification. Warning is exit code 255 (-1) and it's treaded as success

storage.title: web_hooks.slack_general
storage.description: You can add webhook info under web_hooks object and then use property name (e.g. slack_general) to specify that webhook in notification options, instead of using full url. Use either url string (like this example) or object to specify custom data/options/headers and some other items (see example below)

storage.title: web_hooks.slack_info.data.channel
storage.description: Add custom key to request body (e.g. to specify channel)

storage.title: web_hooks.slack_info.textkey
storage.description: By default cronicle message is added as text key on webhook request body. Use this config if you need to use something else (e.g. markdown, html, etc). You can specify nested key too using dot notation e.g. 'data.mytextkey'

storage.title: web_hooks.slack_info.compact
storage.description: (Notification webhooks only) Include only basic info in payload (id, title, action) and your custom data. Useful in case of key conflicts

storage.title: web_hooks.slack_info.token
storage.description: This is a shortcut for web_hooks.slack_info.headers.Authorization = Bearer xoxp-xxxxxxxxx-xxxx

storage.title: web_hooks.slack_info.url
storage.description: Specify webhook url (for object). If using incoming webhooks then just specify it as string (see slack_general example above)

storage.title: oninfo_web_hook
storage.description: Special webhook - will fire on info message, e.g. server startup/restart/error. Those messages appear on activity log

storage.title: universal_web_hook
storage.description: Special webhook - will fire on each job start/completion

storage.title: onupdate_web_hook
storage.description: Special webhook - will fire on metadata update (e.g. on event update)

storage.title: ui.live_log_ws
storage.description: Turns on classic websocket api for live log

storage.title: params.sql.demo
storage.key:
SELECT * FROM
SOMETABLE s 
WHERE s.col = 30
storage.description: params config (object) can be used to set placeholders in shell scripts. You need to check 'resolve parameters' box in event parameters. To set placeholder use square braket syntax, e.g. for this parameter you should use [/sql/demo]

storage.title: _read_me_
storage.description: Those keys are applied right after storage and webserver init, and then can be updated at runtime (no need to restart cronicle). Please note that you cannot override storage/webserver parameters. To add nested config (object) use dot syntax, e.g. servers.host1. If you convert some nested key into string it would erase related subkeys from config object. In this case just remove that string key and click reload button . To check actual config state use Config Viewer link

lines: First time installing?  You should configure your settings in '/opt/cronicle/conf/config.json'.
Next, if this is a manager server, type: '/opt/cronicle/bin/control.sh setup' to init storage.
Then, to start the service, type: '/opt/cronicle/bin/control.sh start'.
For full docs, please visit: http://github.com/jhuckaby/Cronicle
